Margarita comenta que antes de dedicarse a las costuras se desempeñaba como maestra de cocina en un local de comida, sin embargo debido a un problema de salud, debió cambiar de rubro, sin embargo hace 2 años fue operada, por lo que ahora se encuentra solo en tratamiento y controles médicos. Su horario de trabajo es de lunes a viernes durante las tardes, los fines de semana se dedica a vender sus productos. 
Sus insumos los compra en la comuna de Independencia, ya que los precios son a bajo costo. 
Con el crédito comprará una máquina de coser recta y telas para realizar sus servicios de costuras. El resto del crédito lo invertirá en la compra de parafina, ya que durante la temporada de invierno aprovechará de vender.
Sus metas en su negocio son instalarse en un local establecido para ofrecer y vender sus costuras, esto le brindaría mayor tranquilidad y comodidad para su salud. 
Margarita vive junto a su hijo de 28 años de edad, quien trabaja de manera dependiente.
Sus sueños a nivel personal son reconstruir su casa con material solido para no pasar frio durante el invierno. Ella tiene ubicada en un terreno que le cedieron. Otro de sus sueños son poder brindarle ayuda de manera voluntaria a personas más desvalidas, por lo que actualmente se encuentra preparando almuerzos en una casa abierta para abuelitos.
Margarita está muy contenta y agradecida de los créditos y servicios obtenidos a través de Fondo esperanza. Gracias a las capacitaciones impartidas en las reuniones del grupo del Banco comunal ha podido, administrar y organizar mejor su negocio. Comenta que las relaciones interpersonales en el grupo son muy buenas, el grupo es muy unido y realizan diversas actividades, que van fomentando esta buena relación. 
Pudahuel es una comuna del sector poniente de Santiago (capital de Chile), región Metropolitana. Es un vocablo del mapudungun (lengua mapuche) que se traduce como “lugar donde se juntan las aguas” o “lugar de charcos”, debido a que posee una variada red fluvial compuesta por el río Mapocho y los esteros Lampa, Carén y Las Cruces, lo que favorece sus suelos para la producción agrícola por la existencia de abundante agua subterránea.
texts.en:
Margarita is part of the communal  bank "Amaican" in Pudahuel, in the city of Santiago. She sews clothing for the home, such as tablecloths and curtains. She makes a certain amount of clothing, stores them in individual bags and then travels around the area where she lives to sell what she has made. To her older clients she offers credit facilities. Her workshop is located in her own home where she has worked for the last 13 years. Margarita says that before becoming a seamstress, she was a cooking teacher at a food store. However, due to health reasons she had to change direction. However she was operated on 2 years ago and now only has to undergo treatment and checkups. She works Monday through Friday in the afternoons and spends her weekends selling her products.  

She buys her consumables in the town of Independencia as the prices are inexpensive. With the loan she will buy an overlock sewing machine and fabric with which to run her sewing business. The remainder of the loan she will use to buy paraffin as she will make the most of the winter season to sell. 

Her business goal is to set up her business in a permanent location to offer and sell her sewing products. This would give her great peace of mind and be good for her health. Margarita lives with her son who is 28 years old and depends on others for work. Her dreams at a personal level are to rebuild her home with solid materials to keep them warm during the winter. Her house is located on a piece of land that was given to her. Another of her dreams is to help the less fortunate on a voluntary basis: she already prepares lunches at an open house for the aged. 

Margarita is very happy and thankful for the loans and services provided by Fondo Esperanza. Thanks to the training sessions given at the meetings of the communal bank group she has been better able to organize and administer her business. She says that the interpersonal relationships within the group are very good. The group is very united and undertakes diverse activities which encourage these good relationships. Pudahuel is a community in the western sector of Santiago (the capital of Chile), a metropolitan district. The name comes from the word magpudungun (from the Mapuche language) which means a "place where the waters meet" or  "place of puddles". because it has a diverse river network, comprising of the Mapocho river and the Lampa, Caren and Las Cruces streams which make the land here a good place for agriculture due to the abundance of underground water.

loans.use: to buy an overlock sewing machine and fabric with which to run her sewing business.

loans.name: Cangrehilla Group

texts.en:
Ritchel is married with one child. She is 27 years old and lives in Luy-a, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur.

Ritchel sells vegetable to earn a living and has had this business for seven years, even before she married. She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer for their farm.

Ritchel has been a member of PMPC for less than two months. In the future, Ritchel hopes to acquire her own farm area. Ritchel is the leader of a five-person group. Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has their own business,

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is aged 26 and married, with a 4-year-old child. He has been in farming for 3 years and currently employs one farmhand.  Samuel's farm produces milk, maize and beans. He also operates a motorcycle transport business.

Samuel has made his first loan request from Juhudi Kilimo for a loan of 61,600 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says this loan will help him improve his business and the well-being of his family. He hopes to expand his farm by adding three more dairy cows.

Samuel notes that farmers face the challenges of common dairy animal and poultry diseases.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and poultry

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Maria tiene 42 años de edad, es madre soltera de tres hijos.

Ella es una mujer muy luchadora, desde hace seis años se dedica a la elaboración de pupusas, ella manifiesta que trabajo para otra persona y fue ahí donde aprendió a elaborar las pupusas. Pero Maria es visionaria y quiere tener su propio negocio, para lo cual manifiesta que necesita construir un chalet, donde las venderá y elaborara. 

La señora Maria antes de aprender a elaborar pupusas, trabajaba como jornal en una finca de café, cortando el café, limpiándolo y podando fincas, etc. Hoy en día ella tiene el objetivo de tener su chalet, por lo que esta solicitando un préstamo a Fundación Campo, para comprar cemento, arena, bloque y pago de mano de obra, para construir el chalet y la otra parte la utilizara para comprar insumos para elaborar las pupusas y surtir el chalet y tener más producto que ofrecer a los cliente, ya que ella ha visto una gran oportunidad de obtener buenos ingresos, ya que en donde ella vive no hay un chalet donde vendan pupusas.

Por tal razón ella podrá brindarles a sus hijos una mejor condición de vida y de desarrollo, creando una cultura de ahorro, ya que de los ingresos que obtenga mejorara su casa construyendo una habitación más y que sus hijos continúen con sus estudios.

La señora Maria manifiesta seguir trabajando con Fundación Campo, su sueño es tener un negocio más fuerte y con mayores ingresos, al mismo tiempo continuar trabajando en las cortas de café ya que la temporada se acerca, de esta manera obtendrá otra fuente de ingresos.
texts.en:
Maria is 42 years old. She is a single mother with three children. 

She is a fighter and has been in the business of making pupusas (tortilla rellenas). She says she began in this field by working for someone else, and it was there she learned to make pupusas. But Maria is a visionary and she wants to have her own business for which she declares that she needs to build a little café where she could prepare and sell them. 

Before Maria learned to make pupusas, she worked as a day laborer at a coffee plantation, harvesting coffee, cleaning, and pruning and doing other miscellaneous chores. Today she has the objective of getting her café and this is the reason she is asking for a loan through Fundación Campo, in order to buy cement, sand, blocks and to pay to have the work done to build the café and also in order to buy supplies to make her pupusas and to stock the café and to have more products to offer her customers. She has already seen a great opportunity to earn a good income because nobody else is selling pupusas in her neighborhood.

In this way she could give her children a higher standard of living and she would create a culture of saving, since the income that she earns would improve their house from constructing an extra room where her children could continue with their studies. 

Maria says she plans to continue working with Fundación Campo. Her dream is to have a strong business with higher income and at the same time continue working harvesting coffee, as the season is approaching, and in this way have another source of income.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, blocks and to pay the worker to build a little café, and the supplies she needs to make tortilla rellenas

loans.name: Jenina's Group

texts.en:
Jenina's group is comprised of five hard-working women. Jenina is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kamwenge in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children. For the past three years, Jenina has been working hard to manage her small grocery store, which sells dry foods like maize and coffee. 

To help expand her business, Jenina has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food and supplies, and will help Jenina to generate greater profits and improve her family's quality of life. Jenina hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house. 

Jenina is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Jenina's future prospects by helping her to learn how to take care of customers.

loans.use: to purchase more food and supplies,

loans.name: Cruz

texts.es:
Cruz, solicita nuevamente un préstamo porque está motivado por seguir cultivando maíz y yuca, pues dispone de terreno para hacerlo producir, él comprara insumos como el abono, que es tan necesario para la producción y el crecimiento del cultivo. El préstamo anterior le permitió tener su buena cosecha, pago a tiempo la deuda y por eso desea continuar trabajando con la institución.
La condición familiar de Cruz está cambiando, debido al buen trabajo que realiza, por el momento disponen de parte de la cosecha para alimentarse.
texts.en:
Cruz is again applying for a loan, because he wants to continue planting corn and yuca, as he has land that he can farm. 

He will buy agricultural supplies such as fertilizer, which is so necessary for the growth and output of these crops. The previous loan allowed him to have a good harvest. 

Cruz paid his debt on time, and that is why he wishes to continue working with the institution. His family's standard of living is improving; due to his good work, for the time being they have part of the harvest to live on.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Celline

texts.en:
Celline is 38 years old, married and blessed with four children.  She does tailoring to earn a living.  She has been in the business since 1999.  

She expresses gratitude to Faulu Kenya, because she has managed to grow her business.  This is because she has boosted her business with her previous loans from Faulu Kenya.  She also has managed to employ one person to assist her in the business.  

Celline hopes to open other outlets in the future.  She needs 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy fabric.

loans.use: to buy fabric

loans.name: Buffallo Group

texts.en:
Harizon is the facilitator of the Buffallo group. Harizon and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Harizon takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Harizon had a very good maize yield harvesting 9 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Harizon was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Harizon and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Harizon will educate his children.

In 2012, the members of Buffallo group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Tauva

texts.en:
Tauva is 39 years old, married, and has five children. Tauva bakes and sells cakes in the local community. She has two years of experience in this business. Tauva needs a loan of 1,500 WST to to purchase flour,sugar,baking powder , cooking oil and baking pans. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 200 talas or US $83 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Tauva joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Tauva's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase flour,sugar,baking powder , cooking oil and baking pans

loans.name: Ognatan Group

texts.fr: Le groupe OGNATAN est composé de deux personnes qui sont des amies et qui habitent le même quartier. C'est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Félicienne est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Félicienne est âgé de 36 ans et vit au Bénin. Félicienne a arrêté l’école au niveau primaire. Félicienne est mariée à un certain Diallo. Le couple a un enfant scolarisé et à leur charge. Félicienne vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Afin d'assurer les diverses charges de la famille, Félicienne vend depuis six ans, divers produits (conserves, etc.) dans une boutique au Bénin. Félicienne s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Félicienne sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe OGNATAN, un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: OGNATAN is a group composed of 2 friends who live in the same neighborhood. This is the first time that this group requests a loan from ALIDÉ, in order to increase their business. The group representative, Félicienne, is the one raising her hand on the picture. Félicienne is 36 and lives in Benin. She quit school at the primary level. Félicienne is married to a man named Diallo. They have one dependent child, who goes to school. Félicienne lives with her husband and her child. In order to meet the financial needs of her family, Félicienne has been selling miscellaneous items (canned food, etc.) in a shop in Benin. Félicienne buys those items in a market in Benin. In order to meet the needs of her customers as well as to increase her sales and her income, Félicienne, along with the other members of OGNATAN, is applying for this first loan from ALIDÉ.

loans.use: to buy miscellaneous items (canned food, etc.)

loans.name: Jesugnon-Ayimlonfide Group

texts.fr: JESUGNON-AYIMLONFIDE est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres sont des amis et vivent dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe nommée Honorine (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) âgée de 34 ans n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Honorine est mariée à un chauffeur du nom de Isaie. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Honorine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Pour ce faire, Honorine vend de la bouillie à base de maïs et de l’ail de façon ambulante depuis dix ans dans sa région. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Honorine ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe JESUGNON-AYIMLONFIDE sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The Jesugnon-Ayimlonfide Group is made up of three friends who live in the same neighbourhood. The group representative, Honorine (the woman with her hand raised in the photo), is 34 years old. As a child, she did not receive an education. Honorine is married to a man named Isaie, who works as a driver. The couple has four children in their care, who are all currently receiving an education. Honorine lives together with her husband and their children. Together, the couple meet the costs for their household expenses. In order to meet these expenses, Tatiana sells corn gruel on the street. She has done this for the last 10 years throughout the local area. In order to further strengthen their buying power and better satisfy client demand, Honorine and the other members of the Jesugnon-Ayimlonfide Group are requesting their third loan from Alidé. Their previous loans have been paid back in full.

loans.use: to buy corn, sugar and garlic

loans.name: Benkadi  2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 04 membres du groupe BENKADI 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  46 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à Kapala, un des villages de SIKASSO, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide avec Mamou debout  en première position de la gauche vers la droite sur a photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants et la semence pour entretenir : 0,5 hectare. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village, et à SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 105.000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.

loans.use: Achat d’intrants et de semences agricoles

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To Transform her retail shop to a wholesale shop

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza I. lives in Aghsu city where she owns a small furniture store. She is 56 years old. She is a widow with three children. Liza has owned her small business for the last nine years. With this loan she wants to expand her inventory and provide her customers with more selection.

loans.use: purchase more inventory for her store

loans.name: Blanca R.

texts.en:
Blanca sells dresses, perfume and cosmetics door to door, mostly in offices. She is 45 years old and has two university-aged daughters. She doesn't have a shop, but is what in Bolivia is called a "runner". She sells on credit, showing customers pictures of the goods in magazines or catalogs and delivering them the same day, or at least within 24 hours, then collecting her own pay every fifteen days. This is the third loan she has taken out through IMPRO and she has a first-class record of repayment. This loan will pay for her daughters' university education because she is the only earner in the family. She is eligible for this loan on the strength of her work and credit history, and she will be able to repay it.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Blanca vende trajes, perfumes y cosméticos, repartiendo en las oficinas. No tiene un puesto fijo ya que es promotora lo que en Bolivia comúnmente lo denominamos corredoras. Tiene 45 años y dos hijas en edad universitaria. Sus ventas son al crédito ya que trabaja solo con muestras en revistas y ella les entrega el mismo día o máximo después de las 24 hrs.realizando las cobranzas cada 15 días. Es la tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento muy bueno de pago de su obligación. El monto solicitado será destinado para el pago de los gastos de educación universitaria de sus hijas ya que la señora es separada y es la única que solventa los gastos de su familia. Su trabajo y antecedentes crediticios con Impro le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio, el cual le da ingresos para cubrir el préstamo.

loans.use: To pay for her children's education.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: A LAPO group leader, Mrs. Eunice O. is 38 years old.  She started her business in1993. She is a popular seller in her quarters in Nigeria. She plans to improve her business with the loan amount.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her clothing business.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica G. is 43 years old. She is married and has three children and lives in the Kibera slums. Monica also takes care of her nephew from Meru since the harsh conditions back in the rural part of the country he is from do not allow him to get a stable job.

Monica’s motivation to involve herself in the business of spinning wool was influenced by her mother who was an expert in that trade. Monica then decided to learn more and went through two months of training from her neighbor whom her mother had employed. Her mother could not train her since she was always busy delivering orders from clients. 

Having been equipped with the necessary skills, Monica decided to start her own business in the year 1993. This was after she got married and the business helped in sustaining her family since at this time, she was living with her mother-in –law, who also helped her to buy a spinning machine for her business. She struggled to bring up her business until she was able to save Ksh 3,000.00 (USD 45) with which she added an electric machine to her business, to help with the spinning, since it could do the work faster. G. goes to Nakuru once every month, and buys wool weighing 150-200kgs. She has so far been able to employ three workers who help in combing the wool after which Monica spins it into thread ready for sale. She sells the thread in different areas because she has customers as far as Ongata Rongai, Kikuyu and Limuru (regions within the country). She usually combs about 7kgs of wool per week. Her mother-in-law is now very grateful because Monica is able to supporting her.

Monica is requesting for a loan of USD 325 to enable her to purchase a large stock of wool. The loan will help raise the capital for her business hence the business will expand. This will in the long run raise her family income thus will be able to meet all the family needs. The loan repayment period is 12 months.

loans.use: To purchase wool for spinning

loans.name: Lanh

texts.en: Mrs. Lanh K. U., age 37, works raising and selling pigs. Her husband works as a broker buying and selling wood and charcoal, earning around $5/day. They have six children, four who are students and two who are married and live away from home. She requests a loan of $1000 to purchase additional fuel supplies for her husband’s inventory. This will increase his sales and raise the family’s income level.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of fuel.

loans.name: Petrona

texts.es:
Petrona G. is a single woman with two children. Currently, her business is located in the central market of Chinandega. She runs a small grocery store which she started 32 years ago. According to her, she started this business when her children were still young so she could take good care of them. Now she only lives with her daughter, who works with her in the grocery store.

Petrona has worked with CEPRODEL for 2 years. She tells us that she feels very happy with the credits that have been offered to her because they have been very timely and offered in an efficient manner. They have let her buy merchandise that she didn't offer in the past.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Petrona G., es una señora soltera, con dos hijos. Actualmente tiene ubicado el negocio en el mercado municipal en Chinandega, el negocio de ella es una pulpería y lo comienza hace treinta y dos años, según dice ella, este negocio lo emprendió cuando todos sus hijos estaban pequeños, y que de esa venta pudo preparar a sus hijos, en la actualidad ella solo vive con una de sus hijas, que es la que trabaja con ella en la pulpería.

Esta señora, trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace dos año, nos manifiesta que se siente muy bien con los créditos otorgados pues han sido muy oportunos y brindados de manera muy ágil, y que en su momento le han servido para compra de mercadería que no la tenia en existencia.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Famil

texts.en:
Mr. Famil G. is a low-income vulnerable person. He is 32 and lives together with his people in Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in Caucasus region.

Famil rents a barber's. He serves clients and at the end of each month pays for the rent. The business is going well, but Famil's barber shop isn't in good condition and needs to be renovated immediately. Otherwise Famil could incur the risk of losing clients. This winter he applied for $500 to Normicro Saatli branch.

After getting the loan and renovating the shop he plans to collect more customers and increase his daily income.

loans.use: For renovations

loans.name: Kamala

texts.en:
Kamala M., a 64-year-old woman lives in Sainbu-Bhaishapati, Lalitpur. She lives with her son, daughter-in-law, and daughter, and with her granddaughter. Her son works in a department store. Her daughter-in-law and daughter work in a noodle factory. Her granddaughter is in primary school.

Mrs. M. is a farmer in Sainbu-Bhaishapati village. She prefers to grow seasonal vegetables on her land. She sells her vegetables in local market in the morning and in the evening.

Now she is requesting for her second loan of Rs 15000.00 to buy seeds and fertilizers for her farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Justina

texts.en: Justina A. sells provision and food. She is married with 9 children and 40 years old. She has been in business for 4 years. She hails from Uromi, Edo State, Nigeria and needs the loan of $875 to buy more provision and food to sell.

loans.use: To buy provision and food to sell

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 28 year old poultry farmer. He is married and lives with his wife and one child. His wife works as a social worker with Millennium Development. Martin started his poultry business in 2005. He keeps only local breeds (for meat and eggs), which are preferred most locally and he currently has 100. He requires $500.00 to build a bigger structure, purchase chicken feeds, and add more chicks.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To build a bigger structure, add more chicks, and purchase feeds.

loans.name: Vazira

texts.en:
P. Vazira is 44 years old. She is married with three children. Two of her children attend the university and the third one is finishing school but will soon attend the university as well. Her husband is a cook in the local restaurant.

In the picture Vazira and her friend Ibodat are trading alongside on another, that is why they have been pictured together. Vazira is standing on the left side and Ibodat is on the right. Vazira is a market vendor. She started her business ten years ago with only a few products, but her business is currently more stable. Vazira sells fruits and vegetables, such as apricots, apples, strawberries, tomatoes, cucumbers, and many others. Her sons help Vazira with the business. Vazira begins her workday early each morning at 5:00 a.m. In practice, she buys fruits and vegetables from the local farmers, and she then sells such produce in the market, where she is well-known by customers for her friendliness and because she sells her fruits and vegetables for affordable prices. As a result, Vazira’s business generates a stable yet considerable income for her family.

Now is the prime season in which to sell fruits and vegetables, and her goods are (not surprisingly) in high demand. For this reason, she is seeking to purchase fresh fruits and vegetables in order to re-stock her store and to thereby expand her business. Accordingly, she is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,500 Somoni ($450), which she will repay in 8 months. In turn, she hopes to generate additional income in order to pay for her children’s university fees and, with your help, this will be possible. Vazira would like to thank everyone for supporting her.

loans.use: To expand her business in order to pay for her children's university fees by purchasing additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es:
Roberto owns a small newstand. He has 4 school-age children; the oldest also sells newspapers on the weekends in order to help out with his education. His youngest son helps him at the stand. He lives in a small building in a zone located far from the city center, and he has to get up very early in order to be at his stand. This loan will help him add CDs, magazine and books to his stock, and in this way he can increase his income.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Roberto posee un pequeño puesto de periódicos, tiene 4 hijos en edad escolar, el mayor se dedica también a la venta de periódicos los fines de semana para ayudarse así con sus estudios, su hijo menor sale a vender con él, vive en una pequeña construcción en una zona alejada del centro de la ciudad, por lo que tiene que levantarse muy temprano para ir a atender al puesto. El crédito le ayuda a aumentar su mercadería con cd’s, revistas y libros y así incrementar sus ingresos

loans.use: Increase his stock.

loans.name: Ty

texts.en:
Mr. Ty T., 51, makes charcoal to sell. He sells charcoal, transporting it to get it to the customer’s home. T. buys wood from his villagers and some he finds in the forest by himself. He works hard every day and earns around $7 per day. His wife, 50, grows crops to sell and earns around $1.60 per day. They live with two children in Chub Village, Siem Reap Province.

With increasing customer demand, T. wants to expand his wood charcoal making business and needs a small truck to transport his charcoal to sell. Now T. is requesting a loan of US$ 1,200 to add his savings to purchase a small truck to use for his business. The loan will allow him to increase income: using the truck he can transport a lot of charcoal.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To add to his savings to purchase a small truck to use for his business

loans.name: Ahinful

texts.en: S. Ahinful is single and has no children. She has received schooling through junior high. S. sells tin tomatoes, tin fish, Milo and other items at Abura, which she has done since 2006. S. uses her income to pay for utility bills. S. will use the loan to purchase milo, milk and other groceries. With the new profits from her expanded business, S. plans to reinvest and grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase milo, milk and other groceries for resale

loans.name: Mrs. Phon Ry Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank, located in Damank Ampil Village in Kampong Cham Province, consists of fourteen people who plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Phon R. is the village bank president. She is a 50-year-old mother of two children: one of whom is a construction worker, while the youngest is enrolled in the local school. She is also a farmer who owns a two hectare field. She faces a small problem in her plantation, because she does not have enough money to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow her field. Thus, she is requesting a loan in order to pay for this service. With the remainder of the loan, she will buy fertilizers and pesticides to support her crops and make them more productive. Her husband, Mr. Leng Luy, helps his wife on the plantation. The five men shown in the picture above are representing their wives, who are also requesting loans, but who were busy at work and unable to have their photo taken.

This is a village bank loan consisting entirely of end-of-term loans. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product, because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. This type of loan allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term; but most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a 0% default rate on Kiva loans.

loans.use: To hire a laborer with two oxen to plow her field in order to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Maria Mercedes

texts.es:
En el municipio de Nagarote de la ciudad de León la señora Maria Mercedes S. se dedica a su propio negocio de pulpería atendido en su casa de habitación.

Desde hace 6 años que inicio el negocio vendía pocos productos pero a medida que el tiempo ha venido transcurriendo ha mejorado su situación económica por lo que ha vendido mayores cantidades de productos. Esto se lo debe al apoyo obtenido por medio de Ceprodel el cual ha sido un pilar en su pulpería por lo que le ha beneficiado con créditos para obtener sus productos. Una vez mas espera que su crédito sea otorgado para continuar beneficiándose.
texts.en:
Maria Mercedes S. makes a living running her own convenience store out of her home in the Nagarote area in the city of León. She started the business six years ago selling few products but over time she has been able to improve her economic situation, which has allowed her to sell a greater number of products. She credits this to the support she's received from Kiva partner Ceprodel, which has been a pillar to her store. She has benefited from loans to obtain her products. She hopes a loan is granted once more so she can continue benefiting.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products for her convenience store

loans.name: Sovany

texts.en:
Mrs. Sovany S., 37, lives in Kompongtom Commune in Kompong Tom Province. She has three children, two daughters and one son, all of whom are students. Her husband, Mr. Bunthy Peng, is 39 years old and is a policeman.

Sovany sells Kmer Noodle. Her business is mobile so she sells in different areas in her village; she has run her business since 2006. She is now applying for a loan to purchase a new motorcycle for easier transportation.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Henriette

texts.fr: Née vers 1970 à  HÊTIN DOGODO  dans la commune de DANGBO, dame  H. Henriette est mariée et mère de 3enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Elle cultive dans le village de  HÊTIN SOTA  de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement   GF DJIDJOHO DE HÊTIN SOTA  situé à proximité de la source thermale de dangbo ; elle vend aussi de la boisson. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique elle a sollicité un prêt de 110 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1,5hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1970 in Hetin Dogodo, in the township of Dangbo, Mrs. Henriette H. is married and the mother of 3 children, of whom one is enrolled in school. She is a farmer in the village of Hetin Sota in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the group GF Djidjoho of Hetin Sota, located near the hot springs of Dangbo. She also sells drinks.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Benin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Henriette H. has requested a loan of 110,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 1.5 hectares, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 1.5 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en: Epifania S., 34, is married with 3 children. She has less than a year of experience in a chicken business. She sells to the public and village people 5 days per week. She is a new member, with just one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala. SPBD loans are Epifania’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To start her business

loans.name: Zuharla

texts.en:
Married with three children, among them beautiful twins who are currently schooling. Zuharla S. is a 39 year old trader. She believes in hard work and dedication as the primary antidote to minimizing poverty and for that matter she is very serious with her business. She trades in cereals like maize. 

Zuharla started this business when she moved from the northern region. Zuharla has remained in this business for the past four years now.  Through this Zuharla has been very resourceful for her family. She wants to use the loan to buy a larger supply of maize to serve her customers throughout the season. Especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in the country. She believes with the loan she can buy more bags of maize grains from the farmers, avoiding middlemen who retail to her at a higher price.

Zuharla belongs to a village bank called ‘Agnes’. She also hope to receive GH¢400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory. This would enable her to save more to support her husband in taking care of their home.

loans.use: To buy a larger supply of maize

loans.name: Odil

texts.en:
S. Odil is 49 years old.  He is married with four children.  

From the time he was young, Odil began learning to work in the small business with his parents.  With a lot of sacrifice, he became a main producer in agriculture in the area where he lived.  After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice, and seeing his family progressing more and more. 

His hope is to continue growing and improving his business to offer a better future for his children and see them become professional, ethical and hardworking.  For this reason he is asking for a loan of $800 for a term of 12 months.  He wants this loan to buy additional livestock. 

Be an important part of the growth of Odil’s business.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. 

The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  

While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition.  Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.  To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of cattle and small cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Luz Esperanza

texts.es:
La señora Luz Esperanza, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Picota”, vive en el Jr. San Martín Cdra. 06, Distrito D. Picota, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 45 años. 
Se inició, con S/. 100.00 y fue motivada por su esposo, para emprender su negocio, empezó vendiendo revistas, libros, bibliografías, historietas.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta D. cosméticos D. la línea Avon; y mercería, cuenta con un local  acondicionado en su propia casa, donD. ofrece sus productos en stock a sus clientes.

Con el préstamo D. S/1,000.00 que cancelará en un  plazo D. 06  meses, lo invertirá, comprando sus productos como perfumes, colonias, talcos para cuerpo y pies; desodorantes y cremas  pedidos que los hace por catálogo para así poder ofrecerlos a sus clientes a precio mas cómodos que el D. la competencia,  también comprara útiles escolares como cuadernos, lapiceros, borradores ahora que estamos en campaña escolar.

Ella, toma las decisiones en las ganancias D. su negocio. En lo personal, nos cuenta que es más sociable, más segura y responsable con el pago D. sus cuotas. 
 
Luz Esperanza, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Mrs. Luz Esperanza belongs to the "Picota" Communal Bank and lives at Block Nº 6, Jr. San Martin in the District of Picota in the Department of San Martín. She is married and is 45 years old. Motivated by her husband, she started her first business with S/. 100.00 [USD$33], selling newspapers, books, bibliographies and comic books. At present, she sells cosmetics from the Avon line of products; she has a shop in her own home where she offers her stocked products to local clients. With the loan of S/.1000.00 for which she will pay over a period of 6 months, she will invest in buying products like perfumes, colognes, body and foot powder, deodorants, and the creams that are ordered by catalogue. In this way she can offer her clients better prices than her competition. She will also buy school supplies such as books, pencils, erasers since the schools are now in session. She makes the earnings decisions in her business. On a personal level she feels more sociable, more sure and responsible with her loan payments. Luz Esperanza expresses her appreciation to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as an entrepreneur and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of perfumes, talcs, deodorants, and creams.  Purchase of school supplies.

loans.name: Gerardo

texts.es:
El señor Gerardo L. vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Pokeni, ladera norte de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Gerardo trabaja como empleado en una institución de servicio de esta ciudad.
El crédito solicitado es para el pago de matricula y material de estudios, ya que el señor Gerardo esta realizando estudios superiores y se encuentra pronto a culminar sus estudios.
Esta es la primera vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Mr. Gerardo L. lives in his own home in the Pokeni zone on the north side of La Paz city. Gerardo works as an employee in a service institution in this city. The loan is to pay tuition and school materials, as Gerardo is studying at the university and will soon be finishing his studies. This is the first time he is seeking a loan and the socioeconomic analysis completed qualifies him favorably and he can access a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Tuition and school materials to continue his professional education

loans.name: Ionatana

texts.en: Ionatana F., 32, is single with 3 children.  She has many years of experience in the popcorn business. She sells to the villagers 5 days per week. She has  previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD).  SPBD loans are Ionatana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase corn seeds, plastic papers, salt and butter

loans.name: Angelica

texts.es: Angélica tiene 43 años de edad, vive con su esposo y con su hijo quien estudia una carrera técnica, viven en su casa propia. Constituyó en su propia casa un negocio de venta de comida, donde brinda desayuno y almuerzo. En esta actividad ya lleva un periodo de 3 años y le va muy bien porque se encuentra ubicada en un lugar muy concurrido. A Angélica le gusta mucho su trabajo porque aprende cada vez más sobre el arte culinario, pues siempre quiere preparar comidas nuevas. Posteriormente le gustaría llegar a tener una pollería, como se le conoce al restaurante especializado en la venta de pollo a la brasa acompañado con papas fritas. Con MFP lleva 7 créditos y le gusta trabajar con su banco comunal porque son unidos y solidarios. El dinero que viene solicitando esta vez, lo invertirá en la implementación de su negocio, con utensilios de cocina e ingredientes para la preparación de sus platos.
texts.en:
Angélica is 43 years old and lives with her husband and son who is studying at technical school. They live in their own home. She started a business in her home selling food, where she offers breakfast and lunch. She has been working at this activity for 3 years now and it is going very well for her because she is located in a busy place. Angélica really likes her job because she continues to learn more about the culinary arts, as she always wants to prepare new foods. In the future she would like to have a pollería, which is a restaurant that specializes in selling barbecued chicken accompanied with french fries. She has had 7 loans through MFP and she likes working with her community bank because they are very close and supportive of one another. The money she is requesting this time will be used for her business, for kitchen supplies and ingredients to prepare food.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy utensils and supplies for her business

loans.name: Widad

texts.en:
Widad is a 51 year old woman who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their child. Widad owns a hairdressing salon. She has requested a loan of 2000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her salon. Widad has been a microcredit client for ten years now and has always paid on time.  
Her previous loans helped her improve her work, as well as her financial situation. Widad is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients well. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. Widad decided on doing her business because of her experience in sales. In the future, she plans on improving her salon.

loans.use: Widad will use the loan to purchase merchandise for her hairdressing salon.

loans.name: Awaou

texts.fr: B. Awaou est née vers 1969 à DASSA dans le Département des Collines au Centre du Bénin. Awaou est mariée à HADA Mamoudou, un éleveur. Awaou est mère de six enfants dont la nommée Adidja est mariée et n'est plus à sa charge. Awaou est à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin depuis près de 10 ans. Awaou vend tous les matins de façon ambulante la bouillie de maïs. Awaou vend aussi les divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.) ainsi que le maïs qu’elle livre à crédit aux bonnes femmes qui sont dans la restauration populaire. Pour renforcer son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Awaou s’est adressée à ALIDé pour avoir de prêt.
texts.en:
B. Awaou was born around 1969 in DASSA, in the Collines Department in the center of Bénin. Awaou is married to Hada Mamoudou, who raises livestock. Awaou is the mother of 6 children, one of whom, Adidja, is married and no longer lives with her parents. Awaou has been in Cotonou, economic capital of the Republic of Bénin for almost 10 years.

Every morning, Awaou walks around selling maize porridge. She also sells various items (candy, cookies; tins of milk, sardines, and tomatoes; sugar, pasta, detergent and dish-washing and toilet soap, batteries, candles, etc.) as well as maize that she delivers on credit to women who do street-side catering. In order to bolster her business and better respond to the needs of her clientele, Awaou has come to ALIDé to request a loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 2 cases of toilet soap and detergent and 10 sacks of 100 kg of maize

loans.name: Nasreen Muhammad Ashiq Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is married to M. A. and they both have resided in a city named Chichawatni in Pakistan for the past 10 years. They are a very hardworking couple. Nasreen baji operates a sewing business to share the financial burden with her husband, who runs a food-selling business in the community. He sells specifically Punjabi foods like Dahi bhalas and samosas. He has been doing this business for the past five years. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) to grow her husband’s food-selling business.

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Najma naheed baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to sell. Bushra baji and Parveen akhtar baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Nasreen baji is working on her sewing machine in this photo.

loans.use: To buy material for food-selling business

loans.name: Massolomani

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et mère de 02 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d’agoè. Elle exerce comme activité le commerce de céréales, les clients achètent plus le maïs que les autres céréales parce qu’il est très utilisé dans la cuisine togolaise pour préparer la pâte et divers autres aliments. Le stock de céréales a diminué, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 7 sacs de maïs.
texts.en:
This woman is married with 2 children, and lives with her family in the Agoè district. She runs a business selling cereals. Her customers buy more maize than any other cereal because it is commonly used in Togolese cuisine to prepare paste and various other foods. Her stock of cereals has diminished, so she is seeking a loan through WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) to buy 7 sacks of maize.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: El Porvenir Group

texts.es:
La Señora Trinidad S. G. de 40 años de edad. Vive con su esposo y mama en una localidad de Veracruz llamada El Porvenir. Esta localidad esta muy cerca del Puerto de Veracruz. Ella es muy conocida en su localidad por ser muy trabajadora y emprendedora.

Doña Trini como la conocen en su localidad  se dedicaba en un inicio a labores de campo junto con su esposo, posteriormente se dedico a la comercializacion de frutas de temporada como lo son el Mango, Zapote Negro, Granada y Ciruela. Sin embargo, este negocio solo es por temporada y es por esto que ella comenzo a comprar y vender cerdos.

Ya lleva 10 años con la compra y venta de cerdos y comenta que le ha hido muy bien ya que con esto a podido tener un mejor nivel de vida.  Soliicitó un credito con Fundacion Realidad ya que tiene pensado invertir en su negocio comprando mas cerdos para vender sus derivados.

Su meta es poder hacer un local para su negocio ya que actualmente lo hace al aire libre y cuando hay mal clima tiene que parar su actividad.

Ella pertenece a un Grupo llamado "El Porvenir" que está formado por otras 9 personas y solicitan un credito de $23,000  los cuales invertiran en sus actividades que son venta de leche, venta de quesos, zapatos, ropa, venta de comida, etc. Todos comparten la meta de mejorar el nivel de vida de sus familias y siguir adelante con sus negocios.
texts.en:
Trinidad S. G. is 40-years-old. She lives in Veracruz with her husband and mother in a town called El Porvenir, which is very close to the Port of Veracruz. She is quite well known in her area because she is so hard-working and enterprising. Doña Trini, as she’s known in her town, started out as a farm worker with her husband, and later earned her living selling seasonal fruits like mangos, black sapote, pomegranates, and plums. That’s only a seasonal business, though, so she started buying and selling pigs, which she’s been doing for 10 years. She says it’s been a really good business because it has allowed her to achieve a higher standard of living. She requested a loan from Fundación Realidad because she plans to invest in her business by purchasing more pigs so she can sell the pork products. Her goal is to be able to have her own store, since she currently sells in the open air and has to shut down when the weather is bad. Doña Trini belongs to a group called “El Porvenir”, along with 9 other people. They are seeking a loan for 23,000 pesos to invest in their businesses, which include sales of milk, cheese, shoes, clothing, food, etc. They all share the goal of improving their families’ standard of living and getting ahead with their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs so she can sell pork products

loans.name: Ramón

texts.es:
El señor Ramón C. tiene 33 años de edad, esta casado con la señora Nancy Lopetegui, tienen 1 hijo y viven en su propia casa que se encuentra situada en el Barrio Buena Vista de la ciudad de Encarnación.

El señor Ramón es propietario de una Sastrería cerca de su domicilio en donde las prendas de vestir para caballeros, es decir los trajes, camisas, chalecos y chaquetas, las confecciona el mismo. El se dedica a esta actividad desde hace más de 7 años y esto siempre le ha permitido salir adelante, cumplir sus compromisos y cubrir los gastos familiares. Su esposa, la señora Nancy trabaja como vendedora en un comercio que esta situado en la zona baja de la ciudad y posee un salario fijo. Mediante este trabajo ella también puede aportar ingresos al hogar y saldar cualquier gasto que se les pudiera presentar.


El señor Ramón hoy DIA esta solicitando el crédito para la compra de telas ya que tiene muchos pedidos para confeccionar y tiene mucha clientela. El monto que solicita es de Gs. 1.400.000.
texts.en:
Ramón C. is 33 years old. He is married to Nancy Lopetegui, and they have 1 son. They live in their own house, situated in the Buena Vista neighborhood in the city of Encarnación. Ramón has a tailor’s shop near his home where he makes and sells men’s clothing, including suits, shirts, vests, and jackets. He has made a living from this activity for more than 7 years, and it has allowed him to get ahead, fulfill his obligations, and cover the family’s expenses. Nancy, his wife, works as a saleswoman at a store in the Zona Baja [a commercial district in the city] and has a regular salary. Because of her job she also contributes to the family's income and helps to pay off any expenses that may arise. Ramón is currently requesting a loan for purchasing fabric, since he has many orders to fulfill and numerous customers. The amount he is requesting is Gs. 1.400.000.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fabric

loans.name: Carmen Rosa

texts.en:
Carmen Rosa is a member of the Miraculous Maria Village Bank. She is 62 years-old, married, and has four children who are over 30 years old. 

Carmen Rosa has a store where she sells household and culinary items, such as plates, cups, pots, frying pans, blankets, comforters, and sheets. She began her business 10 years ago with a few orders selling from her house and on the street. 

For the past eight years, Carmen Rosa has rented a stand in the market. Little by little she has increased her  merchandise. Carmen Rosa has been with FINCA for 1 year. Since joining, she has changed for the better. The loans help her because she is able to invest more into her business. 

Carmen Rosa needs a loan of 1000 soles to invest in pots and comforters and sheets for the coming season. Her dream is to have her own business with a wide selection of products

loans.use: To invest in pots and comforters and sheets for the coming season

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Queen is married with 2 children, and she is 34 years old. She sells sarongs and tailoring materials to make a living. Queen is requesting the loan amount of N 140,000 to purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Raquel Vanessa

texts.es:
La señora Raquel es socia del Banco Comunal “Primero de Agosto” de distrito de Zepita, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno; tiene 22 años de edad, estado civil casada, tiene 02 hijos, vive en el Jr. 28 de Julio 583, ella estudio educación secundaria completa.

La señora viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 2 años, su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual le permitió incrementar su capital para su negocio de compra venta de comida.

En la actualidad requiere de un nuevo préstamo de S/. 2300.00 Nuevos soles, el cual le permitirá comprar arroz, azúcar, fideos, verduras, condimentos, combustible, etc. para la preparación de comida, el cual vende en su pequeño restaurante.

Su mayor deseo es poner un restaurante grande o una polleria.

A ella le  gustan  los ahorros, y las reuniones
texts.en:
Sra. Raquel is a member of the Communal Bank “Primero de Agosto” (First of August), which is located in the District of Zepita, Chucuito Province, Department of Puno. She is 22 years old, married, and has 2 children. Raquel lives in Jr. 28 de Julio 583 and completed her high school education.

She has been working with Manuela Ramos for 2 years. Her first loan of 300 soles provided additional capital for her food business. She is now requesting a new loan of 2300 soles to buy rice, sugar, noodles, vegetables, condiments, propane, and other items for preparing food. She sells her dishes from her small restaurant.

Raquel hopes to have a larger restaurant or open a chicken shop. She enjoys her savings and the Communal Bank meetings.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, noodles, vegetables, condiments, propane, and other items

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: 51-year-old Teresita G. manages a sari-sari (variety) store in Lila, Bohol.  She started her business in May of 2008.  She has four children.  She considers her business as small but wants someday to be successful in life. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to request a loan of Php 9,000.  She needs this to buy more groceries for her store and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Dinar's Group

texts.ru:
Динар живёт в г. Карабалта. Она лидер этой группы. Динар в разводе и у неё трое детей. К счастью двое сыновей уже подросли и сами зарабатывают себе на жизнь. Старшему сыну двадцать один год. Он работает в г. Бишкек. Второму сыну двадцать лет. Он выучился на сварщика и работает по профессии. Младшей дочери пятнадцать лет. Она учится в средней школе. Свои сорок пять лет Динар успешно занимается животноводством. Она копила средства и когда накопила достаточную сумму ,при первой же возможности купила двух телят. Это сравнительно недавнее её занятие. Так как этим делом она занимается всего последние пять лет. Не смотря на то, что животноводство не вполне женское дело Динар довольно быстро приобщилась к нему, и ей удалось заметно улучшить свой жизненный уровень. Её месячный доход составляет около тысячи сом. Чтобы удовлетворять повседневные нужды, Динар продаёт молоко, а когда ей нужна большая сумма денег, она всегда может продать кое-что из своей живности. Оба сыновей и дочка всегда помогают своей матери по мере возможности. Поэтому Динар не испытывает больших трудностей в уходе за скотом. Сейчас Динар нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить тёлку. Она хочет откормить и перепродать е	ё. Динар вовсе не собирается уходить на постоянный отдых. Она хочет максимально помочь своим сыновьям жениться и дать высшее образование дочери. 
 Динар имеет три партнёра по группе: 
Гульмире пятьдесят один год. Её муж работает на стройке. Сама Гульмира предоставляет услуги массажиста. У них трое детей. Двое уже работают, а младшая дочь учится в университете. Гульмира обратилась за кредитом с целью купить дойную корову. Она планирует дома открыть комнату массажиста, научить младшую дочь делать массаж.
Майрамкуль пятьдесят лет. Она мать пятерых детей. Старшей дочери тридцать, а младшей всего одиннадцать. Майрамкуль занимается розничной торговлей продовольственных товаров в собственном киоске. Майрамкуль надеется получить кредит и вложить средства в бизнес для увеличения товарооборота, а на оставшуюся часть средств закупить уголь на зиму.
Качкын пятьдесят три года. Она мать четверых детей. Муж Качкын работает на стройке. Сама же разводит скот и занимается перепродажей. Качкын нужен кредит для того, чтобы купить телёнка. У Качкын много планов. В ближайшем будущем она собирается приобрести мебель, автомашину, женить сына и отремонтировать сарай.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Dinar lives in Kara-Balta. She is the leader of this group. Dinar is divorced and has three children. Fortunately, her two sons have already grown up and work for a living themselves. Her eldest son is twenty-one years old. He works in Bishkek. Her second son is twenty. He studied to be a welder and now works in the trade. Her youngest daughter is fifteen years old and studies in high school. The forty-five year old Dinar has a successful animal husbandry business. She put aside capital and, when she had saved enough, purchased two calves at the first opportunity. Her business started relatively recently. She has been running the business for the last five years. In spite of the fact that animal husbandry is not traditionally thought of as women’s work, Dinar has quickly become familiar with the business and has been able to noticeably improve her standard of living. Her monthly income is around a thousand som. To meet her daily needs, Dinar sells milk and when she needs a large sum of money, she always can sell one of her animals. Both of her sons and her daughter always help their mother to the best of their ability.Therefore, Dinar is not experiencing large difficulties with managing her livestock. Now Dinar needs a loan to purchase a calf to rear and resell. Dinar isn't planning to go away on a permanent vacation. She wants to help her son get married and her daughter go to college.

Dinar has three partners in her group:

Gulmira is fifty one years old. Her husband works in construction. Gulmira herself provides massage services. She and her husband have three children. Two are already working and the youngest daughter studies at college. Gulmira is asking for credit in order to purchase a dairy cow. She plans to open a massage room in her home and to teach her youngest daughter how to give massages.

Mairamkul is fifty years old and a mother of five. Her eldest daughter is thirty and the youngest is only eleven. Mairamkul works in retail and sells groceries in her own kiosk. Mairamkul hopes to receive a loan and invest the capital in the business to increase turnover and use the remaining funds to purchase coal for the winter.

Kachkyn is fifty three years old and a mother of four. Kachkyn's husband works in construction. She herself raises cattle and resells them. Kachkyn needs a loan to purchase a calf. Kachkyn has many plans. In the near future, she plans to acquire furniture, a car, fund her son's wedding and repair her barn.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Amanda Ross, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy, rear and then resell a calf to finance son's wedding and daughter's education

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda S. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Minda is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Minda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Minda has been engaged in her business for over 40 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Minda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Minda is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Savino

texts.es:
Savino tiene 56 años, vive con su pareja y sus 2 hijos: Walli de 16 y Elizabeth de 18 años de edad; ellos viven juntos en su casa propia.

Desde hace 15 años se dedica a la venta de pan, actividad con la que cubre los gastos de su familia. Él trabaja para una panadería y el se encarga de vender a su clientela, la cual cada día va creciendo. Savino siempre ha trabajado solo y está muy acostumbrado, pero muchas veces le resulta cansado realizar su trabajo por las grandes distancias que tiene que recorrer.
Para el futuro desea tener algo más estable, como una bodega o algo parecido, aún no lo ha pensado muy bien, pero sabe que para eso aún hace falta mucho trabajo y que todo gran sueño se logra poco a poco.

Este es su primer crédito con MFP, dice ser una persona puntual y responsable, por lo que no tendrá problemas con el pago de las cuotas. Con el dinero que solicita comprará pan en mayor cantidad para venderlo y aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Savino, 56, lives with his life partner and their two children: Walli, 16 and Elizabeth, 18. They all live together in their own home. For the past 15 years he has sold bread, a line of work that produces earnings to cover household expenses. He works for a bakery and his job is to sell to his clientele which is growing daily. Savino has always worked alone and is used to it but sometimes doing his work can be exhausting because of the great distances he has to travel. For the future, he would like to have something more stable, like a grocery store or something similar; he hasn't figured it out yet. But, he knows that for that to happen he still has much work to do and every great dream is reached little by little. This is his first loan with MFP. He says he is a responsible and puctual person so he forsees no problem with repayments. The funds requested will be used to buy a greater amount of bread to sell so that his earnings will improve.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase stock inventory.

loans.name: Mrs. Samoeun Inn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. SamoeU. I. owns a small restaurant. She is 31 years old and the mother of a child who is enrolled in the local school. Her husband, Mr. Lay SaroeU., is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He needs some money to pay for plowing the field and to buy pesticides. Mrs. SamoeU. I. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose.

Eight people who live in Prey Ta Mau village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan. They will use their loans for different purposes. Mrs. SamoeU. I. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

loans.use: To pay for plowing and pesticides

loans.name: Gregorio Jr.

texts.en:
Gregorio Jr. M. is from the village of Poblacion 1 Clarin Misamis Occidental. He is 50 years old and married with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Gregorio Jr. owns and operates a transportation services business. Gregorio Jr. has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Gregorio Jr. joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gregorio Jr. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC and is now requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to repair his existing vehicles for better service. This loan will be the 17th loan taken out by Gregorio Jr. from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing transport vehicles

loans.name: Rumbo Al Exito Group

texts.es:
La Sra. Luz, tiene 59 años y junto a sus amigas conforman el nuevo grupo “RUMBO AL ÉXITO” ella es la  presidenta y tiene muchas expectativas para que su grupo progrese.
Luz siempre ha trabajado, hizo de todo para ayudar en la economía familiar  actualmente ella tiene un negocio de venta de ropa en un mercado de su ciudad su negocio esta prosperando poco a poco vende ropa para niños y adultos tanto de primera como de segunda, también alquila habitaciones en su casa lo cual le genera otros ingresos adicionales, gracias a esto ha podido ayudar en la construcción de su casa  y lograr que su hija pueda estudiar, ella quiere superarse un poco mas. por eso desea seguir invirtiendo en su negocio para que este crezca,  el  préstamo de EDAPROSPO lo utilizara para comprar mas ropa para vender  a toda su clientela.

* La Sra. Luz es la segunda de la derecha (parada) con polo a rayas
texts.en:
Luz is 59 years old and together with her friends forms the new group 'Rumbo al Éxito'. She is the president and has lots of experience, for which reason the group progresses. Luz has always worked. She did everything she could to help with the household finances. She has a clothing sale business in a market in her city. Her business is prospering little by little. She sells children's and adult's clothing, as much of the first as the latter, and also rents rooms in her house, which generate additional income. Thanks to this she has been able to help in the construction of her house, and ensure that her daughter can study. She wants to improve a little more, and for this wants to continue investing in her business so that it grows. The loan from Edaprospo will be used to purchase more clothes to sell to her clientele. Luz is the second from the right (standing up) with the striped polo.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Togetherness Group

texts.en:
Augustine K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Togetherness. He is single with five children who range in age from 4 months to 18 years old. He also takes care of his girlfriend and her child.

Augustine has an electronics repair business in the Red Light Market, which is the biggest market in Liberia. He has been running this business for eight years, and he hopes to grow his business into a bigger shop in the near future.

Augustine says he repairs electronics very well in order to encourage customers to continue coming to his shop for repairs. Augustine will use this loan to purchase additional spare parts such as antennas, resistors, and capacitors. He dreams of improving the living conditions of his family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Augustine is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socioeconomic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and LEAP puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional spare parts such as antennas, resistors, and capacitors

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es:
Leonor tiene 30 años de edad, vive junto a su esposo en casa de sus suegros, ubicada en el distrito de La Unión, en la provincia de Piura, de la región Piura, a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a la venta de chicha (bebida tipica de la región) y cerveza en el domicilio donde actualmente reside. Ella misma prepara la chicha y la ofrece a sus clientes. Este negocio es una fuente de ayuda a los ingresos que percibe su esposo, ya que ambos se encuentran ahorrando dinero para construir su casa.

La chicha es una bebida tipica de todo el país, esta elaborada  base de una variedad de maiz y es muy consumida por las personas que viven en las zonas rurales ya que se cree que les da energía para continuar con sus trabajos.
