Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique elle a sollicité un prêt de 120 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1,5hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1978 in Damè in the township of Dangbo, Mrs. Jeanne A. is married and the mother of 3 children, none of whom are enrolled in school. She is a farmer in the village of Hetin Sota in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the group GF Wangnime of Hetin Sota, located near the hot springs of Dangbo. She also sells corn (maize) and flour.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Benin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Jeanne A. has requested a loan of 120,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 1.5 hectares, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 1.5 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Siu

texts.en: Siu T., 67, is married with 6 children. She has many years of experience in a plantation business. She sells to the general public 3 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Siu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase taro tops, sacks of fertilizers, chemicals and farming equipment.

loans.use: To purchase taro tops, knives, crowbar, fertilizers and chemicals.

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario C. vive con su esposa y su hijo en la calle 7 de agosto de la zona de Tacagua de La ciudad de La Paz se dedica a la confección de traje de caballeros, con esta actividad el mantiene a su familia, no percibe ningún otro ingresos mas, el crédito que solicita es para comprar material para atender a sus clientes y de esta manera mantener su fuente de trabajo.

El señor fue cliente de Impro y pago muy bien por lo tanto puede acceder a un nuevo credito.
texts.en:
Mario C. lives with his wife and son in the city of La Paz. He makes men’s suits for a living. Hhe supports his family with this business, but it is his sole source of income. He needs this loan in order to purchase fabric so that he can better serve his customers and, in so doing, keep his job. Mr. C. was a previous client of Impro. He made his payments on time, which means he can request a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday A. is 32 years old, married, and has 2 children. He has a pharmacy where he sells medicine. He is requesting a loan amount of  $700 (100,000 NGN) to purchase more medicine to sell. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Amina

texts.fr: Amina B. est âgée de 32 ans, mariée et mère d’un petit garçon. Elle est coiffeuse à Atakpamé, une ville située à 150 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale du Togo. Elle souhaite avec ce crédit acheter 2 séchoirs et aussi acheter des mèches et produits de beauté pour la revente. Elle compte sur ce crédit pour améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Amina B., age 32, is married and the mother of a little boy. She is a hairdresser in Atakpamé, a city located 150 km from Lomé, the capital of Togo. She would like to use this loan to buy two hair dryers and also to buy some hair extensions and beauty products in order to improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two hair dryers, hair extensions, and beauty products for resale

loans.name: Léonie

texts.fr:
Âgée de 30 ans, H. Léonie est originaire de Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique du BENIN dans le département de l’Ouémé. Léonie est mariée à GOUDJEMINDJI Moïse, un  pêcheur de profession. le couple vit en location avec leurs 6 enfants dont deux filles et quatre garçons tous scolarisés à GANKPODO un quartier de la ville de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Léonie vendait du pain les matins et de beignets les soirs à son domicile. Mais depuis quatre (4) ans, Léonie vend du soja et du maïs en gros et en détail à son domicile. Léonie achète ses produits dans les villages du Bénin et les vend aux grossistes du grand marché international du BENIN. Léonie reçoit de plus en plus de demande. C’est pourquoi Léonie sollicite un quatrième crédit à ALIDé pour renforcer son capital afin de satisfaire ses clients.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Léonie H., 30, comes from Porto-Novo, administrative and political capital of Benin, in Ouémé province. Léonie is married to Moïse Goudjemindji, who works as a fisherman. The couple live in a rented apartment with their 6 children, 2 daughters and 4 sons, all of them enrolled in school, in Gankpodo, a district of the city of Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin.

Léonie used to sell bread in the morning and fried dough in the evening, out of her home. However, for four years now, she has been selling soy beans and maize wholesale and retail, out of her home. Léonie buys her products in the villages of Bénin and sells them to wholesalers in the big international market in Bénin. Léonie receives more and more requests for her products. That is why she is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé to bolster her working capital so as to satisfy her customers' needs.

The word "Alidé" in Fon, the native language of Benin, means "there is always a way for the poorest". Benin is a small country in West Africa, next to Nigeria; its Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita is US$ 1,500. Alidé offers special 0% interest rate loans to very vulnerable persons and the organization is part of a group which will soon launch a micro-health insurance program to beneficiaries of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sacks of soy beans and maize

loans.name: Shoira

texts.en:
A. Shoira devotes herself to the production of wheat, corn and vegetables on her land. For this reason, she remains as long as possible on her land, dedicating herself to the care and fertilization of her fields. With all this effort, it is possible to obtain a good harvest and sell the products, with the aim of offering her three children an education and personal development appropriate to their age. This hard work also prompts her to think of opening a grocery store in her house, thus providing a larger share of income for the family’s kitty. However, this will require a larger investment, and so with this object in mind Shoira is asking for your help in order to obtain the amount asked for to invest in the purchase of a larger quantity of seeds and fertilizer. We hope to count on you, and appeal to your collaborative spirit.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice M. is married, has three children, and has received an education through senior high school. She sells food supplies like rice, sugar, Milo, and milk in Siwdo, which is near Cape Coast.  She has been in this business since 2004.   While Eunice works as a trader, her husband is employed as a mason in the same area.  Eunice is responsible for paying utilities and feeding her family.  Her loan will be used to buy more food supplies for resale. She hopes to use the profits from her business to reinvest back into its expansion.

loans.use: to buy more food supplies for resale

loans.name: Evarito

texts.es:
Evarito tiene 35 años, está casado y tiene 2 hijos. Se dedica a la fabricación y venta de artículos en cuero (fundas para armas de todos los calibres, cintos de cuero, y porta celulares de cuero). El cuenta con clientela fija y posee un taller en su domicilio en donde fabrica estos artículos y las entrega por pedido y a la vez realiza ventas a personas particulares o negocios que los vuelve a vender.

El crédito lo destinara a la compra de materia prima (cuero vacuno). Con esta actividad mantiene a su familia con los gastos básicos y también cubre los gastos del colegio de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Evarito is 35, is married, and has 2 children. He makes and sells items out of leather (gun cases, belts, and cell phone cases). He has a fixed clientele and has a shop in his home where he makes these items. He takes orders for them and sells them to individuals or to business that resell them. This credit will go towards purchasing raw materials (leather from cattle). With this work, he supports his family and also pays for his children's educational expeneses.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase leather

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi N. is twenty-six years old. She is married and has two children, a boy and a girl, both of whom are in the primary school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dwenase, a commercial town in the western region of Ghana. Her husband works at a local sawmill firm.

Naomi sells rubber and plastic products, such as buckets, bowls, and cups in the market square. She buys her goods in Kumasi. Naomi also treks to other markets to sell. She has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk. She hopes to expand her business and give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy plastic ware

loans.name: Salma Muhammad Saleem Group

texts.en:
Salma Baji helps her husband by operating a sewing business. Her husband, M. S., sells mobile phones. He buys used sets and sells them to customers. He has been in this business for the past three years. Salma Baji is applying for a loan to buy more mobile phones for her husband’s business. She is seated second from the right, sewing clothes on her sewing machine.

This loan is for five people and the other members of the group are: Akhtar Naheed Baji wants a loan to repair her sewing machine for sewing clothes. Samina Kosar Baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics and a hair dryer for her parlor. Kalsoom Akhtar Baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her tailoring center. Hanifan Baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her drug store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy used mobile phones to sell

loans.name: Cecily

texts.en:
Cecily W. is a married lady with one child. She runs a new clothes shop in the city of Nairobi. Some of her clients are walk-in customers, and others are regulars.

Cecily has been in this business for the past two-and-a-half years and has never borrowed from any financial institution before. This will be her first loan from KADET, to which she was introduced by a friend.  She will use this loan as working capital to buy more new clothes to resell.

In the future, Cecily hopes to expand her business to a larger shop and open others within the city center.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more stock of new clothes to resell.

loans.name: Carolina Raquel

texts.es:
Raquel es socia del Banco Comunal Amauta.
Raquel es soltera y tiene 43 años, Raquel tiene una tienda en casa de sus padres en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, frutas, bebidas, carnes, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Raquel necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de bebidas.
Los sueños de Raquel son salir adelante con su negocio y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Raquel is a member of the Amauta Community Bank. She is 43 years old and single. Raquel has a shop in her parents home where she sells general grocery items, such as vegetables, fruits, drinks and meats, and she works there every day. Raquel is requesting a loan of 1000 soles (approximately $350), which she plans to use to purchase drinks. Raquel's dreams are to keep making progress and expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beverages

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es: Maruja tiene 42 años, vive con sus hijas: Nelsy de 21, Mindi de 18 y Junior de 12 años de edad, en su casa propia. Desde hace 3 años se dedica a la venta de colchones, los cuales ella misma elabora en su propio taller, el cual implementó en su casa, a base de mucho esfuerzo y dedicación, ya que las cosas no fueron nada fáciles. Hoy en día Maruja produce a la semana 12 colchones con ayuda de un maestro especialista y un ayudante, quienes elaboran los colchones para que ella solamente trabaje en las fundas y forros, los cuales confecciona en su máquina de coser. Posteriormente distribuye su producción en su vecindario y también los vende en el mercado Huamantanga, el más conocido de su distrito. A pesar del pago que hace a las personas que trabajan con ella, las ganancias que le quedan son favorables, por ello Maruja está contenta porque tiene muchos sueños de incrementar su producción y en el futuro tener una fábrica grande y mejor implementada. Este es su quinto préstamo con MFP y está muy agradecida porque los préstamos anteriores que ha tenido siempre la han ayudado a sacar adelante su negocio. Con el dinero que ahora solicita quiere comprar mayor cantidad de material para elaborar sus colchones y aumentar su producción.

loans.use: Compra de materiales

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es:
La señora Alicia es socia del Banco Comunal “Generación 2000”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Santa Rosa Mazocruz, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 21 años de edad, estado civil conviviente y es madre de 02 hijos, estudio educación primaria incompleta (3er grado), vive en el Jr. Puno S/N.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 2 años,  su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que lo invirtió en la compra de carne de ovino y alpaca. 

En este momento ella solicito un préstamo de S/. 3000.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de carne de vacuno, ovino y alpaca, para venderlo en las ferias zonales, además comprara también arroz, azúcar, fideos, aceite, etc.para verder en su tienda.

Su sueño es mejorar su negocio seguir trabajando y educar a sus hijos.

A ella le gusta la forma de trabajo y los ahorros.
texts.en:
Alicia is a member of the community bank Generación 2000 which is located in the district of Santa Rosa Mazocruz, province of El Collao, department of Puno. She is 21 years old, lives in a civil union marriage and is the mother of 2 children. She attended school through third grade and lives in Jr. Puno S/N. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for two years. Her first loan was for 300 nuevos soles which she used for the purchase of sheep and alpaca meat She is currently asking for a loan of 3,000 nuevos soles so she can buy beef, sheep and alpaca meat and will sell it at the local market. She will also buy rice, sugar, noodles, oil, etc to sell in her store. Her dream is to improve her business, continue working, and educate her children. She enjoys her work and savings.

Translated from Spanish by Colleen Godfrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of beef, sheep and alpaca meat, rice, sugar, noodles, oil, etc.

loans.name: Léontine

texts.fr: K. Léontine est née en 1981 à Adja au Sud du Bénin. Mariée à MISSIFAN Clément, un commerçant, et mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés, Léontine réside depuis quatre ans à Abomey-Calavi toujours au Sud du Bénin. Grâce aux revenus tirés des ventes, Léontine participe aux charges de la famille. Léontine est une couturière qui exerce également une activité de vente de produits vivriers (maïs, haricot, soja), et de condiments de sauce. Léontine achète ces différents produits à Azovè, Adja et Glo, les villages du Bénin et les vend à domicile. Léontine a déjà quinze (15) ans d’expérience dans ce domaine. Léontine ambitionne développer son activité, mais il lui manque des moyens financiers pour y arriver. C’est pour cela que Léontine sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé.

loans.use: Achat de 2 sacs de 100 kilogrammes de maïs, 1 sac de 100 kilogrammes de soja et 10 paniers de piments

loans.name: Yut

texts.en: Yut S. is an older village woman and a widow - her husband died of senility years ago. She currently lives with a daughter, as her two other children are married and have already started new family homes. To earn a living, Yut S. cultivates a rice crop and has been farming since 1979, while her daughter sells a few grocery items for a profit. In the past, Yut S. hired a farmer’s cow to help plow her farmland. She hopes to reduce her farm expenses by using a Kiva loan to buy a pair of cows for plowing. With the remainder of the loan she will support her daughter’s grocery business. She and her daughter are pictured.

loans.use: To buy a pair of cows for plowing

loans.name: Charito

texts.en: Charito L. is from the village of Biasong. She is 42 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Charito owns and operates a manufacturing business, manufacturing and selling clay products to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Charito joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Charito is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 10th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en: Mrs. Sareth H. is a villager in Sman Pream village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice in order to make a living. Her husband, Mr. Dath Sokheng, is a vegetable seller. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for selling vegetables door to door. Mrs. Sareth H. is the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because this child is only one year old. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for selling vegetables door to door.

loans.name: Samira

texts.en: Samira is a 40-year-old married woman and has one child. Since 2004 she has been producing detergent products, which she sells in the neighboring villages. Today, Samira is requesting a loan of $1,200 USD to buy necessary materials to increase her business production.

loans.use: To buy materials for detergent production

loans.name: Simona

texts.es:
La señora Simona es socia del Banco Comunal “Tupac Amaru I” desde hace 2 años atrás del distrito y provincia de Yunguyo, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 35 años de edad, estudiò primaria completa, es conviviente y tiene 5 hijos quienes dependen de ella. 
Simona se dedica a la compra y venta de telas y nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo incrementar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 3,000.00 nuevos soles con los que podrá comprar telas.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su tienda de telas en Juliaca. 
Lo que màs le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y los regalos.
texts.en:
Simona has been a member of the communal bank, "Tupac Amaru I" for 2 years in the district and province of Yunguyo, in the department of Puno. She is 35 years old, she finished primary school, and lives with her partner and has 5 children who depend on her. Simona is dedicated to the buying and selling of fabric and told us that with her first loan from the Movement of Manuela Ramos of 300.00 soles she was able to increase her capital. She is asking for a credit of 3,000.00 soles with which she will will able to buy fabric. Her dream for the furture is to have a fabric store in Juliaca. The things she likes most about the communal bank are the savings and the gifts.

Translated from Spanish by Cara Gutterman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Fabric

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary E. is from the town of Gomez, San Isidro, Isabela. She is 57 years old. Mary is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Mary E. group.

Mary is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Mary owns and operates a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Mary has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1500 PHP weekly for these activities.

Mary joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan will be the fourth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Thouch

texts.en: Thouch S., 46, is a widow and lives with her relatives in Kompongchnang Province, Cambodia. S. sells groceries at her home in the village. She is able to earn an income of USD $2.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. She has been doing this business since 2002.  S. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. And they are seeking to improve their businesses as well to help with the daily necessary expenses. As a result, S. is requesting a loan of US $600 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to buy more groceries to stock her store. This is her second loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock her store

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma A. is from the village of Maningcol, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Norma is married and has three adult-aged and two school-aged children. To make a living, Norma owns and operates a hog raising business. She has been engaged in this business for twelve years and makes approximately $88 a month.

In 2007, Norma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC. Norma is requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 6th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Shalom 3 Group

texts.en:
Natividad is the coordinator of her group Shalom, and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Hato Mayor, a poor agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her child.

Natividad is excited to be taking her seventh loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business making and selling candy by purchasing ingredients such as sugar and coconut as well as a machine to slice and dice the coconut. She will use the profits to invest in her home by buying furniture and a fan as well shoes and notebooks for her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Sugar, coconut and a machine for cutting and shredding coconut

loans.name: Freddy Rene

texts.es:
El Sr.Freddy, tiene un transporte de radiotaxi por la zona sur, tambien se dedica por temporadas a la venta de arena juntamente con su cuñado, y también se dedica a colocar tepes (cesped que se coloca en los jardines) en domicilios con su esposa, quien se dedica a esta actividad, a la vez venta de abono, tierra en su puesto ubicado en la zona de Achumani, son una pareja joven que viven en la casa de su mamá, tienen dos hijos pequeños, quienes acompañan al puesto de venta de su mamá. El Sr. Freddy trabajo anteriomente con grupo "Sastres", tiene buena predisposicón y voluntad de pago, el crédito invertirá en algunos repuestos para su transporte y para la compra de una puesto en la zona de Achumani para la esposa, es un cliente que solo trabaja con nuestra institución.

El Sr. Freddy esta agradecido con Emprender Y Kiva por la Confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Freddy drives a radio dispatch taxi in the southern zone and sells sand seasonally with his brother-in-law; he also installs tepes (green sod that is installed in gardens) in homes with his wife, who has this business and also sells manure and planting soil in a stand in the Achumani area. They are a young couple who live in his mother's house; they have two small children, who keep their mother company in her sales stand. Freddy collaborated with the "Sastres" group previously and has a good predisposition to repay his loan. He will use the funds to buy some vehicle replacement parts and to buy a sales stand for his wife in the Achumani area. He is a client that works exclusively with our institution. He is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust placed in him by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tires and a sales stand.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a 40-year-old married mother of two children. She currently lives in Likoni, Mombasa region, but is originally from Nyanza province.

Pamela, who initially owned a secondhand clothes and fish business, now owns a nursery school. This she initiated from her small savings in 2000 after many years of hard work and personal sacrifices. Her business is currently doing well with the number of pupils increasing day by day.

Pamela has applied for Ksh 40,000 to put up more classrooms. She has big plans and hope that her business will transform itself into a high school in future.

loans.use: To build more classrooms

loans.name: Thary's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Thary T. is a village bank president who has selected by 27 members and they all live in Dei Edth Kaoh Phos village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for a different purpose.  Mrs. Thary T. is a vegetable seller who earns a small income to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Mrs. Thary T. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. Her husband, Mr. Sopheap TH., is a Cambodia rickshaw driver to earn a living. Mrs. Thary T. is 28 years old and a mother of two children. One of her children is a student in the local school and one is a vegetable seller who helps with the mother's business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Nicida

texts.es:
Nicida tiene 20 años de edad, es soltera y tiene dos hijos. Actualmente vive en la localidad de Palmapampa, ubicada en la hermosa selva ayacuchana, donde tiene su casa propia.

Se caracteriza por ser una persona innovadora, a pesar de que sus allegados se oponían a que realice su proyecto porque ya había varias tiendas del mismo rubro. Pero aun así decidió incursionar en la venta de abarrotes, incorporando nuevos productos que su competencia no ofrecía. Nicida sabe muy bien que el financiamiento es el primer desafío para iniciar cualquier negocio, por lo cual lo tomó con mucha responsabilidad y seriedad para que su nuevo proyecto se convierta en realidad. También tiene experiencia en agricultura, ya que desde su adolescencia ayudaba a sus padres, pero desde que tuvo su primer hijo decidió independizarse, aunque sus padres la siguen apoyando en su negocio.
Por lo general atiende desde las 6:00 AM hasta las 9:00 PM y a pesar de que su negocio tiene pocos años de funcionamiento, está obteniendo buenos resultados de manera paulatina.

Este es su primer ciclo con MFP, por el cual se compromete a seguir cumpliendo con sus respectivos pagos en las fechas determinadas.  Asimismo, tiene confianza en su banco comunal por la seriedad con la que todos trabajan. El dinero solicitado le servirá para comprar más mercadería y surtir su tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Nicida is 20 years old, single, and has two children. Currently, she lives in the Palmapampa locality, located in the beautiful Ayacuchana jungle, where she has her own home. She is known for being an innovative person. Despite being advised by her close family and friends to not sell grocery items because there already existed shops that did, she decided to anyways, incorporating new products that her competitors didn't have. Nicida knows very well that financing is the first challenge to starting any new business. As such, she took on this new project with a lot of responsibility and seriousness in order to make it a reality. She also has experience in agriculture, having helped her parents since she was an adolescent, However, after having her first child, she decided to become independent, even though her parents continue to support her and her business. In general, she works from 6 am to 9 pm and even though her business has only existed for a few years, it is slowly obtaining very positive results. This is her first cycle with MFP and as such, she promises to continue paying her determined payments within the deadline. She also has a lot of faith in her communal bank by the seriousness with which everyone works. She plans to use the money that she has applied for to purchase merchandise with which to stock her grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise.

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
Consuelo L. is from the village of Olingan, Dipolog City. She is 54 years old. Consuelo is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Consuelo owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Consuelo is just starting this business.

In 2010, Consuelo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Consuelo is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Consuelo from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely J. is from the village of Letican, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 52 years old. Fely is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Fely owns & operates a specialty food stall in the local community. Fely has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Fely joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and the ability to engage in business activities. Fely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional bowls and food containers needed in her food stall. Fely is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Fely from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Ma. Bella

texts.en:
Ma. Bella P., 38 years old,  is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Bella owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Ma. Bella has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

Ma. Bella joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Bella has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Bella is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Ma. Bella from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle B. is from the village of Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 27 years old. Michelle is single. To make a living, Michelle owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily-use products in the local community. Michelle has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Michelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Michelle has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Michelle is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Michelle from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Aracelys Maria

texts.es:
Aracelys S. A. de 29 años vive en la Urbanización la Playa y se dedica al negocio de alquilar lavadoras y a ofrecer servicios de Internet, transcripciones, inpresiones y fotocopiado;  está casada y tiene 2 hijos de 6 y 9 años de edad.

Hace tres años se interesó por tener una actividad adicional a las comidas rápidas en las que ya venia trabajando, así fue como le agregó la de servicios de lavandería comprando una máquina primero  y luego otras dos,  justamente con el crédito que le hizo a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo en el año 2008; organización de la que es cliente hace dos años y hace seis meses decidió comprar un computador con recursos propios,  para abrir un nuevo servicio el de Internet, también compró una impresora y una fotocopiadora. Así es como, Aracely en cada momento le ha ido abriendo espacio a toda su infraestructura de servicios  que ahora tienen una  mayor demanda, por eso ha  decidido comprar más equipos y trasladarse  a un local cercano a su vivienda, para cumplir su sueño de extenderse cada día más. 
Su esposo es un gran trabajador de una empresa privada y juntos han logrado conseguir todo lo que hoy tienen para el bienestar de su familia. Aracely no tiene empleados o colaboradores, ella trabaja sola y administra bien su tiempo para cumplir con todo, como esposa, madre, en fin buen miembro de familia. Como sus transcripciones las hace con una buena calidad tiene varios clientes que aprecian su amabilidad y buen trabajo, por eso es muy popular y todos la buscan para recomendarle sus trabajos.

Aracely es una joven con mucha capacidad de superación y una enorme fuerza de trabajo que la hacen admirable. Ella es muy feliz porque esta trabajando en lo que sabe hacer,  pues estudió secretariado ejecutivo sistematizado, lo que le facilita el manejo efectivo de su negocio y porque también  se actualizó a través de cursos y seminarios que la actualizan constantemente.

Los créditos de la Fundación han sido para Aracely muy funcionales le han servido para comprar su lavadora y de sus utilidades toda la infraestructura con la que hoy cuenta. Con su credikiva de ahora va a comprar un computador, muebles y enseres, para adecuar su negocio; adicionalmente pagará un mes de arriendo por anticipado, en el local que próximamente ocupará negocio y este cambio es justamente un buen desafío.
texts.en:
Aracelys S. A., 29, lives in the La Playa urban zone. She rents washing machines and offers Internet, transcription, printing and photocopying services. She’s married and has two children who are 6 and 9 years of age. Three years ago she became interested in having a business in addition to the fast-food business she’d been involved with to date. This is how she installed the laundry service buying first one machine then two additional ones precisely with the loan she got from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo in 2008. She has been a client of this organization for two years and six months ago decided to buy a computer with her own resources to open a new Internet service. In addition, she bought a printer and a photocopier. Thus Aracelys has been constantly opening up new venues in her service infrastructure for which there is growing demand. She has, therefore, decided to buy more equipment and move to a location that is near her home in order to expand even more. Her husband is a valued employee at a private firm and together they have built all they now have for their family’s wellbeing. Aracelys does not have any employees or collaborators; she runs and tends to her business by herself and manages her time in such a way to be a good wife and mother, in other words, a good family member. Because the transcriptions she does are of such high quality, she has several customers that appreciate her kindness and good work. Thus, she is very popular and everyone seeks her out when they need projects done. Aracelys is a young woman with lots of capacity for self-improvement and an enormous willingness to work which make her most worthy of admiration. She is very happy working at what she knows best because she studied to be an executive secretary which makes it easier for her to manage her business and she also stays current through seminars and courses she takes constantly. The loans that Aracelys has gotten from the Fundación have been useful for her to purchase the washing machines and her profits have provided the entire infrastructure she how possesses. She will use her latest Kiva loan to buy a computer, furniture and supplies to set up her business. In addition, she will pay a month’s rent in advance for the locale she plans to install her business in. This change represents quite a challenge for her.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a computer, furniture and supplies to stock the business.  In addition, to pay for a month’s rent in advance for the location where the business will be located.

loans.name: Elimane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Elimane N. est  un  retraité de 67 ans qui vit dans la localité de Yoff dans le quartier de Ngaparou. Il est marié et père de 18 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 6 et 38 ans.
Monsieur N. a pratiqué  l’activité de mécanicien depuis 1964 dans une société de la place connue sous le nom de SAMA ou elle a pris sa retraite depuis 1999. C’est aussitôt qu’il a quitté l’école coranique qu’il a commencé  a apprendre le métier de mécanicien. Son occupation préférée  était  de dépanner les voitures.
Monsieur N. est membre de la caisse de Yoff depuis avril 2007. Il sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs prévu   pour la réfection  de la dalle de l’une des ses chambres qui et en mauvais état.
Son objectif est d’améliorer  le cadre de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Elimane N. is a 67-year-old retiree who lives in the borough of Yoff, in Ngaparou. He is married and a father to 18 children ranging in age from 6 to 38 years old. Mr. N. started working as a mechanic in 1964 at a local company known as SAMA. He retired in 1999. He had started to learn about being a mechanic soon after leaving Koranic school. His favorite pastime was repairing cars. Mr. N. has been a member of the Yoff branch since April 2007. He is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to repair a damaged slab in one of his rooms. His goal is to improve his family’s living environment.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Slab repair

loans.name: Marianela

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “VAMOS JUNTOS”; La socia esta ubicada en el barrio de Arcopata, perteneciente al distrito de Santiago , provincia y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Marianela; ella tiene 32 años de edad y es madre soltera y tiene 2 Hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el comercio ambulatorio minorista, Ella se dedica a  vender pinturas desde hace 6 años en las ferias o en distintos puntos de aglomeración de personas. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en mercadería.

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our associate is a part of the “Vamos Juntos” (We Go Together) communal bank. She lives in the Arcopata neighborhood, within the Santiago province, in the Cusco department. Marianela is 32 years old and the single mother of 2 children. She sells cosmetics and has been doing so for six years. She sells at the local fairs and at various locations where people gather. She is asking for this loan in order to invest in more merchandise. She is grateful to those who form part of this dream through this medium and she is committed to making her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Juan Francisco

texts.es:
Juan es  de la ciudad de Paraguarí, tiene 24 años y  está cursando el 5° año de la carrera Contaduría Pública en la Universidad Nacional de Asunción Facultad de Ciencias Económicas de la ciudad de Paraguarí.
Tiene una hermana que está cursando el primer año de la carrera de Veterinaria, su madre es docente y su padre es empleado público.
Juan actualmente trabaja en COPACO como empleado en el cargo auxiliar técnico.
Juan tiene muchos deseos de terminar su carrera y habilitar su propio estudio contable, para a contar con un buen ingreso y ayudar a su familia.
El solicita el préstamo para   la compra de libros que está necesitando para estudiar.
texts.en:
Juan is from the city of Paraguari. He is 24 years old and a 5th-year accounting student in the school of Economics at the National University of Asuncion in Paraguari. Juan has a sister who is a first-year veterinary student. His mother is a teacher and is father is a government employee. Juan works as a paid employee at COPACO where he is a technical assistant. Juan very much wants to finish his degree and set up his own accounting firm so that he can earn a good income and help his family. He is applying for a loan to buy the books he needs for school.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy books.

loans.name: Ainash

texts.en:
Ainash M. lives in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan. She is a widow and has three children: two grown daughters, who live on their own, and one son, who is the main light of Ainash’s life.  

She works in a local school in Naryn city and is characterized as a very well-wishing and positive person. As it was very hard to live on a low wage and to bring the children up by herself, Ainash decided to begin her own business in cattle breeding. In 2000, using her initial capital of 10,000 soms (KGS), she bought cattle for fattening and reselling. Because of an absence of appropriate conditions for livestock maintenance, Ainash decided to keep them in the neighboring village, at the farm of her mother-in-law. Such assistance from her late husband’s family serves as an example of the deeply rooted, warm relations between them and Ainash. 

In 2008,  Ainash applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS, which she used to buy more cattle. The revenues from this loan were used to pay for an education for Ainash’s son, who was eager to be a serviceman and successfully entered the military academy. 

Now Ainash intends to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden her business by purchasing 18 sheep and five bull-calves. In the future, using the revenues, she plans to construct her own barn near the house. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Amira  Luz

texts.es: Amira R., ha trabajado mucho con su cónyuge en un negocio que idearon cuando su cuñado les propuso venderle un punto de venta de productos para el hogar,  que ellos surtieron con los primeros financiamientos recibidos de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, organización con la  que han logrado hacerle adecuaciones a su local, incrementar sus ventas y poder educar a sus hijos. Y es que Amira no solo tiene el negocio de mercancía en punto de venta bien ubicado, sino que además elabora empanadas, arepas y otras frituras y las familias de su vecindad se desayunen con sus productos; así mismo en su local puso un servicio de telecomunicaciones o SAI, que fue su primera inspiración empresarial, porque ella dice que una mujer no debe quedarse haciendo los oficios domésticos y con los brazos cruzados, esperando el ingreso de su marido. Amira es una gran trabajadora, se levanta a las 4: 00 AM para preparar la masa y a las 6 se dedica con su madre al oficio de la fritangueria, luego organiza  todo lo que su esposo y un empleado deben llevar a los clientes, porque tiene 2 carretillas donde transportan por todas las calles de Soledad, la mercancía que vende y tiene mas de 500 clientes y este mismo número de tarjetas donde anota los nombre y el valor que de cada uno de ellos recupera semanalmente y que está distribuido en módicas cuotas pero en plazos largos. Su sueño ahora es tener varios puntos de venta y un gran almacén, en la actualidad quiere prepararse para la temporada de fin de año, donde las mercancía que más se comercializas son los juguetes, los electrodomésticos menores y la ropa y eso es lo que justamente quiere hacer con su credikiva, surtirse de estos artículos, porque su gran desafío es la gran competencia del sector y por eso ella venderá lo que su clientela necesite.
texts.en:
Amira R. and her husband have worked hard at their business they started after her brother-in-law suggested they establish a retail outlet selling products from their home. They were able to stock their business using the first few loans they received from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, an organization that has helped them make adjustments to their store, increase their sales, and provide an education for their children. Amira’s retail business is situated in a good location, but this is not the only activity in which she is involved. She also prepares turnovers, “arepas” (flat cornbread stuffed with various fillings), and fried foods that many families consume for breakfast. In addition, she offers telecommunication services from her store provided through SAI, which was the original product she provided through her business.

Amira says she started her business because she did not want to perform household chores all day and then sit around with her arms crossed while waiting for her husband to bring home a paycheck. She is a hard worker who wakes up at 4am to prepare the cornmeal. By 6am, Amira and her mother begin selling fried foods. Later in the day, she organizes the merchandise that her husband and an employee have to deliver to their customers. They have two pushcarts that they use to transport goods through the streets of Soledad. Amira has more than 500 customers, so she has to prepare the same number of invoice cards that state the customer’s name, the amount that has to be collected each week, and the list of products that have been delivered over the long term. Her dream is to have several retail outlets and a large warehouse. She currently wants to prepare for the year-end season when she sells more merchandise such as toys, small appliances, and clothing. For this reason, she plans to use her Kiva loan to stock these items. Her greatest challenge is the high level of competition in the area, so she wants to sell what her customers need.

loans.use: Purchase toys, small appliances, and clothing

loans.name: Chinara's Group

texts.en:
Chinara A. is the leader of the group. She is 48 and is married with two daughters and two sons. The sons are private entrepreneurs and the daughters are students.  Chinara and her husband are farmers who breed cattle and cultivate fruit and vegetables.  They earn 14000 soms per month by selling their fattened cattle and a portion of their harvest.  Chinara is requesting the loan to help pay for dental services.  In the future she wants to purchase a vehicle and build a house for her sons. 

Gulbara K. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 44 and married.  She has a son, who attends university and earns money by selling jeans in the market in his free time.  Gulbara and her husband breed cattle. With money received from the loan they want to purchase a bull in order to resell it at a higher price after fattening it.
 
Gulkair O. is 35 and is married with two daughters. The first daughter is at school and the second is not yet.  Gulkair and her husband are farmers who cultivate fruit and vegetables. Gulkair is requesting the loan to help pay for dental services.

Bahrnisa K. is 52 and is a widow. She has a daughter and a son.  Bahrnisa breeds cattle, and with the money received from the loan she wants to purchase cement in order to build a shed for her cattle. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To pay for dental services

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase of an additional cow for the farm.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem is a resident of Sumandri which is a small city in Punjab Pakistan.  It is famous for its agriculture industry.  She lives there in a Christian colony with her family in a 2 room brick house.  She is a housewife who stays home and does her household responsibilities. Her husband operates a spare parts business. Specifically, he sells motorbikes spare parts through his shop.  He has been doing this business for over 20 years. 

Naseem has given birth to 6 children.  One of them works in the army, while 2 sons work with their father in his spare parts shop.  The remaining three children stay at home.  Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business.  With the loan, he will buy spare parts for motorbikes in bulk quantity so that he can fulfull his customer's orders on a timely basis.
 
She is hopeful that with the help of this loan investment, her husband’s business will grow further and it will result in better financial conditions for the family. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application.  In previous loan years, she has paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Naseem.

loans.use: To buy motorbikes spare parts for the spare parts business.

loans.name: Antonieta

texts.en:
Antonieta F. is a married woman who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Culipapa, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  fishing and fish-selling businesses. Her husband Elmer F., who is 40 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 8 and 17 years old. 

Antonieta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Antonieta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to buy materials for the fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Antonieta F. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase materials for the fishing boat

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a farmer from the town of Kisii in western Kenya. He has been farming for the last fifteen years and employs two farmhands. His main products are tea, maize and beans which he sells at the local market. He  depends solely on the income from his farm to cater for the needs of his family. His biggest challenges in farming have been insufficient funds to purchase farm inputs and diseases which affects his crops.

Charles is 56 years old and married with six children who are between the ages of 14 and 32. Four of the children are currently attending school.

He has requested this loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. The income from the sale of milk will help pay school fees for his children. His family will also be able to have enough milk for domestic consumption. In future, he would like to open a kerosene pump facility to supplement his income.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: María Elia

texts.es: María Elia F., reside en el municipio de Sensuntepeque en el departamento de Cabañas, lugar en el cual vive junto a su hijo de 9 años de edad. María es madre soltera, por lo que trabaja el doble para poder sostener su hogar y a su hijo. Ella se dedica a vender ropa, en su propio negocio el cual esta ubicado en el mercado de Sensuntepeque en donde posee un negocio bastante grande y surtido. María solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de ropa, en diferentes tallas y colores, esto lo hace con el deseo de poder obtener mayor cantidad de clientes y así percibir más ganancias, lo cual es muy importante para ella, debido a que es la única fuente de ingresos que posee para sostener su hogar.
texts.en:
María Elia F. lives in the town of Sensuntepeque, in Cabañas department together with her 9 year-old son.  María is a single mother which means that she works doubly hard to support her household and her son.  She sells clothes in her own business which is located in Sensuntepeque market.  Her business is quite large and well stocked.

María is requesting a loan so that she can buy a larger quantity of clothes, in different sizes and colors.  This way, she hopes to be able to attract more customers and thereby make more profits.  This is very important to her since her business is the only source of income that she has with which to support her household.

loans.use: To buy clothes wholesale

loans.name: Zenfira

texts.en:
Zenfira A. is a married 55-year-old woman living in Sabirabad. She has one son and one daughter, who are both adults. 

Zenfira started her pharmacy business in 2006.  This has become the main source of income for her family. Currently she operates her own chemist's shop, licensed by Ministry of Health of the Azerbaijan Republic. It is located in a good location where there is a lot of pedestrian traffic. 

After successfully repaying a previous loan, Zenfira decided to take out her second loan with Aqroinvest and Kiva. She used the loan of 1500 AZN to broaden her business by buying more medical inventory. Zenfira is doing her best to provide for her children.

loans.use: To buy medical inventory for pharmacy

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita R. is from the village of Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 53 years old, is married, and has 4 school-aged children.

To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from her bakery. Lolita has been engaged in her business for more than 2 years and earns approximately 3,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from the business.

Lolita joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is an individual member of PMPC and is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP that she will use to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her immediate family.

loans.use: Capital and inventory for a bakery

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Sustainability is one crucial part of a business, and it definitely matters to Carmen L., 61, not just in her business but also in her family life. Carmen is married to Francisco, and together they are raising a big family of eight children. Just like Carmen, Francisco is also a vendor. They currently live in Tanza, Cavite.

Carmen is a vegetable vendor offering fresh food options for her fellow community members who have the time to cook their own food at home. Having been four years in business, she knows which kinds are appealing, and which vegetables rarely sell. She also applies her learning from CCT* to her business, and earns around Php12, 880 monthly.

To help her grow her business, she decided on a loan amount of Php8, 000. She intends to use this money to buy more fresh vegetables, such as sweet potatoes, beans, and okra.  Other items for purchase are onions, garlic, and ginger. 

One challenge Carmen faces is the unstable prices of vegetables, which greatly affects her business. Also, she finds it hard to sustain her business capital. Nevertheless, she is on the lookout for solutions to these dilemmas and will see to it that her business will become sustainable. She hopes to be able to save up for emergency purposes, and to be able to further improve her business. Basically, all of these represent her effort to make sure that she will be able to sustain her family’s daily living and support them in reaching for their dreams.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase  quantities of fresh vegetables

loans.name: Thembeka Group

texts.en:
Fikile is 42 years old and married with two children, ages 7 and 20. She runs a small spazza (or "shop") in Mtubatuba, South Africa. She is standing at the front in the photo above, raising her hand.

She's been in this business for five years, selling airtime, cool drinks and chickens from her home. She also earns income from the government’s child support grant. She says that the main challenge to her business is that the customers do not pay on time.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Business and KIVA to buy more airtime and chickens to sell. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her send her children to school. In five years time she would like to build a new shelter for her business. 

She appreciates WDB and Kiva very much.

loans.use: To buy airtime and chickens to sell

loans.name: Caleb Mang'ang'a

texts.en:
Caleb, 26 years old, has been selling basins, wall hangings and frames in Naivasha town for the last 5 years.   His business is in an open area and he is therefore able to attract many customers who are passing by.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his fourth loan.  He repaid all his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan to buy more retail items for sale in his business area. He anticipates good returns from this investment.

In future, Caleb hopes to move to a more permanent place to operate his business from.

loans.use: To buy more retail items for sale.

loans.name: Raimundo

texts.es:
Raimundo, tiene un negocio donde vende maquinaria y equipo de oficina, reside en Usulután, donde vive con su familia, su esposa y dos hijos, Raimundo tiene 39 años e inicio como comerciante por iniciativa propia ya que curso un técnico en programación analista, este estudio lo impulso para instalar su propio negocio, tiene un horario de 8:00am a 5:00pm, pero actualmente necesita financiamiento para comprar maquinaria y equipo de oficina.
Este préstamo le ayudara a realizar la inversión y contara con mejor maquinaria y equipo para fortalecer el negocio. Su objetivo es ampliar el negocio, contar con una línea de productos para ofrecer a los clientes y en su familia pues velar por su tranquilidad.
texts.en: Raimundo runs an office supplies business.  He lives in Usulután with his family; his wife and two kids.  Raimundo is 39 years old and got started in business on his own initiative after studying to be a program analyst.  His studies are what drove him to open his own business, which maintains hours from 8:00 am to 5:00 pm.  Raimundo is currently in need of a loan in order to invest in better office supplies, which will strengthen his business.  His goals are to broaden his business, acquire a line of products that he can offer to his clients and take care of his family’s well-being.

loans.use: To purchase office supplies

loans.name: Amanda

texts.es:
La señora Amanda es socia del banco comunal Nuevas Amigas del Distrito de Calleria, Departamento de Ucayali, tiene 33 años de edad, está casada y tiene 2 hijos.
Son 5 años que viene trabajando con los préstamos de Manuela Ramos y tiene una pequeña bodega bien surtida en su casa.
Con su nuevo préstamo de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos préstamos comprará:  ½ caja de conservas, ½ caja de aceite, 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 1 caja de galletas, 1 caja de lava vajillas, 1 bolsa de legía, 1 caja de azul para ropa, ½ caja de leche, 2 paquetes de papel higiénico,  2 paquetes de gaseosa, etc.
Gracias a este negocio ayuda a su esposo quien trabaja como panificador, con su aporte la vida será más llevadera como pareja y podrán darle a sus hijos mayores comodidades. "Manuela Ramos a favorecido al logro de varias metas".
texts.en:
Amanda is a member of the Nuevas Amigas [New Friends] community bank of the distrito of Calleria, departament of Ucayali. She is 33 years old, married, and has 2 children.  

She has worked with loans from Manuela Ramos for 5 years and she has a small, well stocked store in her house. 

With her new loan of S/. 1,500.00 she will buy: ½ box of preserves, ½ box of oil, 1 sack of rice, 1 sack of sugar, 1 box of cookies, 1 box of dishwashing soap, 1 bag of lye, 1 box of bluing for clothing, ½ box of milk, 2 packages of toilet paper, 2 packages of soft drinks, 

Thanks to this business, she helps her husband, who works as a bread baker, to make their lifestyle better as a couple, as well as to give their children more conveniences. "Manuela Ramos has help me meet many goals."

loans.use: To buy milk, rice, oil and other products.

loans.name: Sum's Group

texts.en:
There are 14 people in this village bank loan group. Mrs. Sum was selected by the members to be the village bank president. 

Mrs. Sum is 39 years old, widowed, and has two children, both of whom attend schoO. and help with the farm.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land, where she grows rice. She also earns additional income by cultivating mushrooms. She is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy fertilizers for growing rice and to cultivate mushrooms.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for growing rice.

loans.name: Pricia

texts.en:
Pricia A. is 50 years old, married and has one adult child. She is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental.  Pricia owns and operates a business where she buys and sells fish in the local community.  She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Pricia joined Kiva partner Gata Daku Multi-purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) to access financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Pricia has successfully repaid a previous GDMPC loan of 10,000 PHP.  Pricia is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase fish and shrimp to sell in the community. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She will use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About Gata Daku Multi-purpose Cooperative (GDMPC):

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fish and shrimp for sale

loans.name: Zulfiya

texts.en:
Zulfiya works in a very successful fabric sales business. She operates a sales location where she offers a selection of trendy fabrics for sewing national women's dresses. Her business has a long history. She was able to start this venture nine years ago, and since that time her business has done quite well. She is quite an entrepreneur and we are happy that she has chosen to apply her talents in a business that helps women be even prettier. 

Zulfiya has requested a loan of 12,000 TJS to give her more working capital to use in her business. It will be exciting to see how Zulfiya's enterprise will continue to grow in the future as she's off to even greater success. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy seasonal fabrics.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: As a married parent with nine children, Josephine works hard to support her family. She makes a living by using bamboo leaves to make nipa, an item used in roofs in Philippines. She also runs a sari-sari (or variety) store. Josephine is applying for a loan for PHP 11,000 from NWTF to buy additional items for her sari-sari (variety) store and to buy more bamboo leaves to use in her nipa-making business. She has already received and repaid four loans from NWTF member, and is committed to earn and save enough money to provide her family with a secure financial future.

loans.use: to buy a bamboo leaves and items to sell in her variety store.

loans.name: Aurenila

texts.en: Aurenila is 45 years of age, widowed, and a mother of three. She has been engaged in the livestock business for almost 21 years. She's asking for a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase livestock feed to supplement her hogs. Her net income when she sells a hog is 20,000 PHP every three months. She is glad that her livestock business income now is enough to support her children’s education. She wants to thank Kiva lenders for their financial assistance in availing the loan and hopes that lenders will continue to fund her loan requests in the future.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed

loans.name: Fidelina

texts.es:
La señora Fidelina,  es  casada  con el señor Celerino  y vive en la localidad de llano grande municipio de coapilla Chiapas
